title: Are GMOs good or bad?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the debate about GMOs heats up when it comes to food and agriculture?

options.label: A
options.text: Because genetic engineering is used in many fields, but the same thing is treated differently in food and agriculture.

options.label: B
options.text: Because humans have been genetically modifying plants and animals for thousands of years.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the debate is mainly about the safety of GMOs.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the debate is mainly about the ethics of GMOs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between selective breeding and genetic engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Selective breeding is faster than genetic engineering.

options.label: B
options.text: Selective breeding is cheaper than genetic engineering.

options.label: C
options.text: Genetic engineering eliminates the factor of hoping for lucky hits.

options.label: D
options.text: Selective breeding is more accurate than genetic engineering.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most common objections to GMOs?

options.label: A
options.text: Gene flow, meaning GM crops could mix with traditional crops and introduce unwanted new characteristics into them.

options.label: B
options.text: Terminator seeds, which produce sterile plants.

multiple-choice.question: Can GM plants run wild entirely?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, GM plants can run wild entirely.

options.label: B
options.text: No, GM plants can't run wild entirely.

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on the type of plant.

multiple-choice.question: Is eating GMO plants no more risky than their non-GMO equivalent?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, eating GMO plants is no more risky than their non-GMO equivalent.

options.label: B
options.text: No, eating GMO plants is more risky than their non-GMO equivalent.

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on the type of plant.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of BT crops?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce a protein that destroys the digestive system of specific insect pests.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce a protein that is harmless to humans.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce a protein that is toxic to humans.

options.label: D
options.text: D: To produce a protein that is resistant to certain weed killers.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the problems with the GMO debate?

options.label: A
options.text: Much of the criticism of this technology is actually criticism of modern agriculture and a business practice of the huge corporations that control our food supply.

options.label: B
options.text: GMOs are not effective in agriculture.

options.label: C
options.text: GMOs are not safe for human consumption.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a positive outcome of using GMOs in agriculture?

options.label: A
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh stopped the destruction of whole harvests by pests.

options.label: B
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh increased the use of pesticides.

options.label: C
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh decreased the health of farmers.

options.label: D
options.text: The introduction of a new GM eggplant in Bangladesh had no impact on agriculture.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a GMO that could improve our diet?

options.label: A
options.text: Plants that produce more or different nutrients, like fruit with higher antioxidant levels that help to fight diseases or rice with additional vitamins.

options.label: B
options.text: Plants that produce less or different nutrients.

options.label: C
options.text: Plants that are resistant to certain weed killers.

options.label: D
options.text: Plants that are toxic to humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential uses of GMOs in agriculture?

options.label: A
options.text: To collect their own nitrogen, like microbes.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce a protein that destroys the digestive system of specific insect pests.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce a protein that is harmless to humans.

options.label: D
options.text: To produce a protein that is resistant to certain weed killers.

options.label: B
options.text: Digging a huge trench, constructing a tunnel, and then refilling the hole

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: About 50 meters deeper than the "cut and cover" lines

options.label: D
options.text: About 100 meters deeper than the "cut and cover" lines

options.text: A competition to see who could fly the highest

title: What causes body odor? - Mel Rosenberg

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why body odor is unpleasant?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the smell of sweat.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the bacteria that feed on sweat.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the combination of sweat and bacteria.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the genetic makeup of an individual.

multiple-choice.question: What type of glands are found in the armpits that secrete proteins and fats?
What is the main function of bacteria in the armpits?

options.label: B
options.text: To feed on sweat and turn it into odorless compounds.

multiple-choice.question: What type of chemicals are responsible for the oniony aroma of body odor?
What determines how strong an individual's body odor might be?

options.label: A
options.text: The resident microbial populations in the armpit.

options.label: B
options.text: The nutrients that the glands provide the bacteria with.

multiple-choice.question: What is a gene variant that virtually eliminates body odor common in?
What happens to the ratio of apocrine to eccrine sweat when an individual is nervous?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove bacteria from the armpits.

options.label: B
options.text: To inhibit bacterial activity and mask odors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of antiperspirants?

options.label: A
options.text: To inhibit bacterial activity and mask odors.

options.label: B
options.text: To form tiny gel plugs that block sweat glands.

multiple-choice.question: What is a possible positive function of secretions from the armpit?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a means of chemical communication.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It's a way to learn about the history of technology.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to learn about the importance of recycling.

options.text: To promote a specific product or service.

options.text: To scare parents into keeping their children safe.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: To show off her weaving skills.

options.label: C
options.text: To challenge Arachne's claims of being a better weaver.

options.label: D
options.text: To punish Arachne for her pride.

options.label: B
options.text: The misdeeds of the gods and their abuse of power.

options.label: C
options.text: The beauty of nature and the world.

options.label: D
options.text: The history of the gods and their conquests.

options.label: C
options.text: Arachne was shrunk into a spider.

options.label: D

options.text: She is remembered as a great weaver.

options.label: B
options.text: She is remembered as a challenge to the gods.

options.text: She is remembered as a symbol of undaunted persistence.

options.text: It represents her talent as a weaver.

options.text: They are her children from her life as a spider.

options.text: They are her children from her life as a human.

options.text: It is a description that shows both positive and negative aspects.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall message of the passage?

options.label: A

options.text: They have a single layer of enamel.

options.label: B
options.text: They have two layers: a hard external cap of enamel and a tougher layer of dentin.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a layer of dentin that is flexible.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which odontoblasts form dentin?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They move outward and secrete dentin as they go.

options.label: C
options.text: They secrete dentin throughout their life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the common form of tooth that first appeared during the dinosaur age?

options.label: D
options.text: To shape the shape of teeth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of removing the front cusp and raising the shelf in the tribosphenic molar?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to survive in extreme temperatures.

title: How does the immune system work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the immune system?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce antibodies to fight off threats.

options.label: B
options.text: To clear bodily toxins and waste.

options.label: C
options.text: To coordinate the body's defenses against infection, illness, and disease.

multiple-choice.question: What are leukocytes, and where do they originate?

options.label: A
options.text: Leukocytes are a type of white blood cells that originate in the lymphatic system.

options.label: B
options.text: Leukocytes are a type of cell that originates in the bone marrow and migrates into the bloodstream and the lymphatic system.

options.label: C
options.text: Leukocytes are a type of cell that originates in the bloodstream and migrates into the lymphatic system.

options.label: D
options.text: Leukocytes are a type of cell that originates in the lymphatic system and migrates into the bloodstream.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of phagocytes in the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce antibodies to fight off threats.

options.label: B
options.text: To destroy foreign cells by consuming them.

options.label: C
options.text: To coordinate the body's defenses against infection, illness, and disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of lymphocytes in the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To destroy foreign cells by consuming them.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce antibodies to fight off threats.

options.label: C
options.text: To coordinate the body's defenses against infection, illness, and disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To stop a threat from escalating to dangerous levels inside the body.

options.label: B
options.text: To eradicate a threat within a few days.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce antibodies to fight off threats.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of a healthy immune system?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps us develop long-term immunity.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us fight off an estimated 300 colds and innumerable other potential infections over the course of a lifetime.

options.label: D
options.text: It produces antibodies to fight off threats.

multiple-choice.question: What is an autoimmune disease?

options.label: A
options.text: A disease that tricks the immune system into attacking the body's own perfectly healthy cells.

options.label: B
options.text: A disease that tricks the immune system into attacking foreign cells.

options.label: C
options.text: A disease that tricks the immune system into attacking the body's own perfectly healthy cells.

options.label: D
options.text: A disease that tricks the immune system into attacking foreign cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the immune system's surveillance over time?

options.label: A
options.text: To eradicate a threat within a few days.

options.label: B
options.text: To stop a threat from escalating to dangerous levels inside the body.

options.label: C
options.text: To help us develop long-term immunity.

title: Why should you read Charles Dickens? - Iseult Gillespie

options.label: C
options.text: His use of satire and social commentary.

options.text: The importance of social class and status.

title: How do fish make electricity? - Eleanor Nelsen

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the electrical signals of fish in underwater environments?

options.text: They use light to navigate and find prey.

options.label: C
options.text: They use electrical signals to communicate, navigate, and find prey.

options.label: D
options.text: They use chemical signals to communicate and find prey.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The weakly electric fish are larger than the strongly electric fish.

options.label: D
options.text: The weakly electric fish are smaller than the strongly electric fish.

multiple-choice.question: How do the electrocytes in the electric organ of a weakly electric fish work?

options.label: A
options.text: They pump out sodium and potassium ions to maintain a negative charge outside and a positive charge inside.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They allow positively charged ions to flow back in when a nerve signal arrives.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the schnauzenorgan in the Peter's elephantnose fish?

options.label: B
options.text: To sense electrical signals from other fish.

multiple-choice.question: What is the two-phased attack used by the electric eel to hunt its prey?

options.label: A
options.text: A series of weak electrical pulses followed by a strong electrical discharge.

options.label: B
options.text: A series of strong electrical pulses followed by a weak electrical discharge.

options.label: C
options.text: A single strong electrical discharge that stuns the prey.

options.label: D
options.text: A series of weak electrical pulses that stimulate the prey's muscles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the electric eel's ability to curl up and overlap the electric fields generated at each end of the electric organ?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the strength of the electrical discharge.

options.label: B
options.text: To exhaust and immobilize the prey.

multiple-choice.question: What is one mystery in the world of electric fish?

options.label: A
options.text: Why they are able to withstand their own shocks.

options.label: D
options.text: Why they use electrical signals to communicate.

title: The Bystander Effect: The science of empathy

multiple-choice.question: What is the bystander effect?

options.label: A
options.text: The more people there are in a group, the more likely anyone is to offer help.

options.label: B
options.text: The less people there are in a group, the less likely anyone is to offer help.

options.label: C
options.text: The more people there are in a group, the less likely anyone is to offer help.

options.label: D
options.text: The bystander effect is a feeling of guilt when someone is in need.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people are in a group and someone needs help?

options.label: A
options.text: People in a group are more likely to help.

options.label: B
options.text: People in a group feel a sense of responsibility and help.

options.label: C
options.text: People in a group feel that someone else will take care of it.

options.label: D
options.text: People in a group are less likely to help.

multiple-choice.question: What is the diffusion of responsibility?

options.label: A
options.text: The feeling of guilt when someone is in need.

options.label: B
options.text: The sense of responsibility to help someone in need.

options.label: C
options.text: The feeling that people in a group feel that someone else will take care of it.

options.label: D
options.text: The feeling of fear when someone is in need.

multiple-choice.question: How long did it take for participants in a group of 10 to offer help?
How long did it take for participants in a group of 5 to offer help?
How long did it take for participants to offer help when they were by themselves?
What was the average time it took for participants in a group of 10 to offer help?
Why did the participants in the group of 10 take a long time to offer help?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they thought someone else would take care of it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were waiting for someone else to make a move.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were not paying attention.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason people in a group are less likely to help?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they think someone else will take care of it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not paying attention.

multiple-choice.question: What can you do to help someone in need when you are in a group?

options.label: A
options.text: Wait for someone else to make a move.

options.label: B
options.text: Offer help even if no one else is doing it.

options.label: C
options.text: Take out your cell phone and take a video.

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is Prometheus a symbol of in mythology?

options.label: B
options.text: He is a symbol of knowledge and progress.

title: Where do math symbols come from? - John David Walters

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.text: To represent a long string of sequential terms added together

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is represented by an exponent

options.label: C
options.text: It is represented by a capital sigma

options.label: D
options.text: It is represented by a number added to another number

options.label: B
options.text: By representing quantities that are unknown

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: By representing sets of numbers and whole equations

options.text: A set of symbols that correspond directly to human symbols
